awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Integration of Conducting Polymers With Living Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Payne, Christine K.    
Proposal Number: 1451903

Advances in neuroscience and neuroengineering require new tools. Of specific need is the ability to interface electrical devices with the brain. The challenge is coupling hard metal surfaces to the soft environment of the brain. To address this problem, the investigators will pursue a novel direction, using soft, flexible, biocompatible conducting polymers to form nanowires within individual cells. These conducting polymer nanowires will provide a new tool for neural probes, bionic implants, regenerative medicine, and the treatment of neurological disorders.

This research will address two specific goals; intracellular delivery of a foreign material into cells and electrochemical polymerization in a protein-rich, high salt, environment. Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) will be used as a representative conducting polymer.  Aim 1 will focus on delivery of the monomer into the cell using the cell's own pinocytic machinery. Experiments will use PC-12 model neurons. Aim 2 will electrochemically polymerize the monomer to form a nanowire within the cell, establishing contacts between external electrodes and the cell.  Each Aim is accompanied by extensive cytotoxicity assays to ensure the cells remain healthy during the process. In addition to the biomedical applications enabled by a hybrid conducting polymer-cell, this research will provide interdisciplinary training at the interface of engineering and life sciences for a diverse group of students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate level.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Interfacing electrically active materials with living cells has important applications for neural probes, regenerative medicine, and the treatment of neurological disorders. The challenge is coupling conducting materials to the soft environment of the cell. For biological applications, conducting polymers have great potential due to both their flexibility and biocompatibility. The goal of this research is to embed a conducting polymer within live cells to create a cell that maintains its normal cellular functions while serving as its own electrically active material. It is expected that these hybrid conducting polymer-cells will be unique tools for the neural engineering community.

 

Water-soluble poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) is used as a representative conducting polymer. Experiments during the last two years focused on delivery of the polymer into the cell using the cell’s own pinocytic machinery. In the first year of this award, two goals were met: 1) we determined the maximum concentration of PEDOT:PSS that can be tolerated during extended cell culture  and 2) we have established a calibration curve to determine the amount of PEDOT:PSS accumulated in the cells as a function of time. During 2016, we finalized cell health assays using a MTT assay of mitochondrial activity. These experiments were carried out by a talented high school student. Her results have allowed us to use EDOT and PSS for cellular experiments at levels at that do not harm the cells.

 

The Intellectual Merit of this research stems from the novel engineering goal; formation of a hybrid conducting polymer-cell. This research addresses two specific challenges; intracellular delivery of a foreign material into cells and electrical measurements of single cells. The ability to incorporate a conducting polymer directly into live cells will provide a transformative approach to neural engineering. 

 

The Broader Impacts arise from the biomedical applications enabled by a hybrid conducting polymer-cell as well as the interdisciplinary training at the interface of engineering and life sciences that students obtain while working in this project. Throughout this project, the Payne Lab hosted a high school student who assisted with many of the cell health assays. In May 2017, she graduated from Coretta Scott King Young Women’s Leadership Academy, an Atlanta public school and will begin classes at Georgia State University next week. She worked in the lab full time during the Summer (2015, 2016, 2017) and spent afternoons in the lab during the academic year as part of Project ENGAGES (Engaging New Generations at Georgia Tech Engineering & Sciences). 

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2017
Modified by: Christine K Payne
